I'll keep my fingers crossed for you that you get a low enough oncotype score to avoid chemo - and at this point, you might as well believe that you will since that is more likely than not...On the flip side, there are many women who are able to get through chemo fairly well without too many issues so you may still be able to spare the kids too many details.

Posts.Content: May 2, 2012 05:57AM doingbetter wrote: I was 48 when diagnosed with an oncotype of 11, saw three oncologists, two were quick to say no to chemo and one said why not - the usual, you're young and healthy and hit it with everything we've got. But the relative percentage benefit was extremely small. While everyone talks about getting through chemo okay, people fail to remember that even if you make it through fine, there is a very real risk of a secondary cancer such as leukemia developing later because of the chemo and that type of leukemia is not easily treatable. While the risk is small, if it is greater than the benefit one might get from adding chemo into the mix, then for these early stage cases with low oncotype scores, I don't think it's as simple as saying hit it with everything you've got since you could be setting yourself up for something worse down the road. I think people really need to think about all the benefits and risks very carefully - not just the immediate side effects. In my case I would have been more worried about the higher likelihood of a more problematic cancer than the small benefit chemo might have offered. Bottom line is none of us, especially in these borderline cases, will ever know if the chemo helped keep the cancer at bay or if we didn't choose chemo and cancer came back would the chemo have made any difference. You just have to really think through all the possibilities and work with trusted medical professionals to reach the decision that is right for you.

Posts.Content: Jun 29, 2010 04:50PM doingbetter wrote: You absolutely must do what you think is best for you.  As someone who has just been diagnosed a second time in the other breast, I can only say the best thing is to have no second guessing yourself.  Might always wonder if you could've/should've done something different, but at least you know you did what you thought was best at the time.  I will tell you my personal experience. I was first diagnosed with DCIS by surgical biopsy 11 years ago. Then had a lumpectomy. It was very small with clear margins so no radiation was recommended at the time. A year later, more DCIS in the same breast. At that time, the choice was either lumpectomy and radiation or simple mastectomy. I'm also quite small and was tired of dealing with it and much more concerned about the radiation than the mastectomy. While no surgery is pleasant, once it's done, it's done and no side effects to speak of - I actually felt better after my mastectomy than my lumpectomies. I also chose no reconstruction, and must say that my woman surgeon was quite dumbfounded. She said none of her young patients would forego reconstruction when given the choice. My children were quite young at the time (I was 38) and I just wanted the simplest treatment so that I could get on with my life and I figured if and when the time came to deal with the second breast, I'd revisit the idea then. Other than the minor inconvenience when getting dressed, it has never bothered me or my husband, for that matter. Now I am dealing with IDC in my other breast and while the tumor is quite small, will again opt for the mastectomy. It is easier to decide that having been through it once before, but again, I prefer the more straightforward treatment. I know mortality may be the same, but personally, I can't deal with the angst of the 6 month mammos/sonos, etc. and suspicions and worries. I've also revisited the reconstruction issue and one thing that is clear is that if it is not an "emotional" issue for you, other than the fact that there will be an additional surgical procedure, it can be done at a later date. I remeber reading somewhere on these boards that you should be sure you really want it before you go ahead - it's easier to go back and reconstruct later than to go back and deconstruct if you're not happy.  So, I figure I need to really want it before I decide to go forward. Then I'll be more willing to put up with any pain, complications, etc. rather than wondering why I put myself through it. At the end of the day, it really has to be your decision which form of treatment your want and are most comfortable with so that you can live with the decision.

I felt most comfortable with and my treatment became clear, I finally started to feel somewhat normal again. I think we all have our own ways to get through this time.  I know some will use some kind of medication.  In my case, I was quite nervous, but just kind of plodded through.  It did help to talk to a few people who had been through it a while back and were doing fine.  But I also did not tell many people so when I was going about my usual daily business I was able to get caught up in the usual routine of things without my condition being the focus.  I can tell you, as I'm sure you have heard from others on these boards, that the diagnosis and waiting stage is emotionally the hardest part.  Sounds like you're almost done with that, so just hang on to that thought.  I can tell you now, while I'm still not thrilled with the situation, I'm pretty much back to normal.  There is always a nagging worry in the back of my mind if something will recur at some point, but as I'm reminded by others something bad could happen to anyone at any time.  And, I have also used this wake up call to adopt an even healthier lifestyle. Not that it's any guarantee of anything, but I sure do feel better.

Posts.Content: Nov 16, 2010 10:58AM doingbetter wrote: I don't think anyone can say for sure that the cancer recurred because they did or didn't do chemo.  Many people who've gotten chemo still have the cancer recur, and it's a known fact that chemo benefits a very small percentage of patients who take it.  That's why it's nice to have the oncotype test - while no guarantee, at least it's another piece to factor into the decision.  Doing chemo carries a whole host of risks aside from just the unpleasant immediate side effects, and the notion of hitting the cancer with all they've got seems a bit overkill if you are in a low risk group when you consider the potential long term harm that chemo can cause.  But, it's a very personal decision that needs to be weighed carefully taking all risks into careful consideration.  Personally, I can't look at chemo as just insurance - if there's strong evidence that one may clearly gain a benefit then I would never say no, but otherwise you are putting yourself at risk for other issues.  Luckily my oncotype score was low enough to have a clear answer, BUT...no one ever knows for sure what's enough so you just have to make a decision that you are comfortable enough to live with.

Posts.Content: Jun 1, 2011 07:22PM doingbetter wrote: Shippy  I know some people are very happy with the microbeads, but I did not like them at all.  I used them for a short time after surgery, then got silicone prostheses as soon as I could.  I had a single mastectomy several years ago so was already used to using a prosthesis, but then had to get another mastectomy last year.  I can't speak for how you will adjust to the prostheses, but aside from it being a little bit of a hassle and adding a few more minutes to my dressing time, the "real" ones (silicone) don't bother me at all.  They look much more real than the microbeads, and once dressed no one would know the difference that they are not "real".  The microbead was not the same - they kept shifting around and looking uneven.  There is a short time after surgery that you may not be able to wear silicone prostheses and the microbeads are an okay stand in, but you do not have to use them forever.  And I actually preffered the "pouffy" type prosthetic (some kind of a fiberfill) over the microbead during the transition time.

Posts.Content: Feb 25, 2011 01:47PM doingbetter wrote: Personally, I liked getting it the same day of surgery. The first surgeon I saw wanted it done the day before, but the doctor I ended up using just scheduled it a couple of hours before surgery time.  The wole BC experience is bad enough without having to stretch things out over a couple of days as far as I'm concerned.  And it did hurt - not awful like some people on these boards describe, but I was sore for a while so would not have wanted to go home and try to go about my business feeling like that.  I figured I was going to the hospital for surgery anyway and that day was kind of shot, so why take time out of my prior day for a medical procedure also.
